metadata.title: Advanced Alpha Calculator (Investment)
metadata.description: Multi-method alpha calculator for investments: single-period CAPM alpha, Jensen-style estimated alpha from regression outputs, and annualized excess return alpha. Includes data entry guidance, accuracy caveats, and references to industry standards for validation and controls.

capm_single_period.label: CAPM Alpha (Single-period excess return)
capm_single_period.description: Calculates alpha as actual asset return minus the CAPM-expected return using a supplied beta. Enter percentage values (e.g., 8 for 8%).

jensen_estimated.label: Jensen-style Alpha (from regression summary)
jensen_estimated.description: Uses mean returns and an estimated beta (from time-series regression) to compute alpha. This mode is for situations where you supply summary regression outputs rather than raw time-series data. Enter percentage values (e.g., 8 for 8%).

expected_mean.label: Expected mean return (decimal) using estimated beta

annualized_excess.label: Annualized Excess Alpha (from cumulative returns)
annualized_excess.description: Computes annualized returns from cumulative total returns and reports the difference between asset and benchmark as annualized alpha. For cumulative inputs, enter decimals (e.g., 0.35 for 35%).

fields.label: Asset return (%) — single-period (enter as percent, e.g., 8 for 8%)
Market return (%) — single-period (enter as percent, e.g., 6 for 6%)
Risk-free rate (%) (enter as percent, e.g., 1.5 for 1.5%)
Mean asset return (%) — e.g., average periodic return (enter as percent, e.g., 0.8 for 0.8% if using monthly)
Mean market return (%) — same periodicity as mean asset return
Estimated beta from regression (β̂) — supply regression output if available
Cumulative asset total return (decimal, e.g., 0.35 for 35%)
Cumulative benchmark total return (decimal, e.g., 0.28 for 28%)

introduction: Alpha measures the portion of a portfolio or asset return that is not explained by market movements or a benchmark model. Different alpha calculations exist for single-period comparisons, regression-based estimates, and multi-period annualized excess returns.

This tool supports multiple validated methods so you can choose the calculation that matches your data: single-period CAPM comparison, Jensen-style calculations using regression summary statistics, or annualized excess from cumulative returns. It includes guidance on input formats and accuracy considerations.
methodology: CAPM single-period alpha is the observed return minus the CAPM-expected return: Alpha = R_p - [R_f + β (R_m - R_f)]. Use this when you have a single observed asset return, a market return, a risk-free rate, and a beta.

Jensen-style alpha here uses supplied summary regression outputs (estimated beta and mean periodic returns). For rigorous regression-based inference, perform a time-series regression of asset excess returns on market excess returns and supply the estimated beta and mean returns from that analysis.

Annualized excess alpha converts cumulative total returns to annualized returns using geometric annualization and reports the difference. This is appropriate when comparing multi-period total returns across different horizons.
how_is_calculated: CAPM alpha formula (single-period): Alpha = R_p - [R_f + β × (R_m - R_f)]. All percent inputs are entered as percentage numbers and converted to decimals internally.
Jensen-style alpha (summary): Alpha = mean(R_p) - [R_f + β̂ × (mean(R_m) - R_f)]. Provide estimated beta from a regression and mean periodic returns in the same periodicity.
Annualized alpha (from cumulative returns): Annualized = (1 + cumulative)^(1/years) - 1. Alpha = annualized_asset - annualized_benchmark.
examples: Example 1 (CAPM single-period): Asset return = 12%, Market = 7%, Risk-free = 1.5%, Beta = 1.2. Expected CAPM return = 1.5% + 1.2*(7% - 1.5%) = 8.7%. Alpha = 12% - 8.7% = 3.3%.

Example 2 (Annualized): Asset cumulative return = 0.50 (50%) over 4 years, Benchmark cumulative = 0.30 (30%). Annualized asset = (1.50)^(1/4)-1 = 10.67%. Annualized benchmark = (1.30)^(1/4)-1 = 6.78%. Annualized alpha = 3.89%.

faqs.question: What input formats should I use?
faqs.answer: For single-period and mean returns, enter percentage numbers (e.g., 8 for 8%). For cumulative multi-period returns used in annualized mode, enter decimal fractions (e.g., 0.35 for 35%). Beta and estimated regression coefficients are plain numeric values (e.g., 1.05).

faqs.question: When should I use the Jensen-style method?
faqs.answer: Use Jensen-style when you have regression outputs (estimated beta and mean periodic returns) from a time-series regression of asset excess returns on market excess returns. That preserves statistical estimation steps and standard error reporting in your source regression.

faqs.question: Does this tool run regressions on raw time-series data?
faqs.answer: No. This tool accepts summary statistics and single-period figures. For full regression analysis, use a statistical package, export the estimated beta and summary statistics, then input the estimates here. Methodology guidance in this page explains required steps.

faqs.question: How accurate are the results?
faqs.answer: Calculations are deterministic given your inputs, but accuracy depends on data quality, correct periodicity alignment, and appropriate model choice. See the accuracy and validation section and consult time-series regression diagnostics for inference.

faqs.question: Are there regulatory or standards considerations?
faqs.answer: Use documented procedures for data handling, model validation, and controls. Follow applicable standards for data integrity and process controls cited below for traceability and reproducibility.

glossary.definition: The portion of an asset or portfolio return not explained by the chosen benchmark model; a measure of excess return relative to expectation.
Sensitivity of the asset's returns to movements in the benchmark or market; used in the CAPM expected return calculation.
The return predicted by the Capital Asset Pricing Model: R_f + β (R_m - R_f).
Geometric average return per year computed as (1 + cumulative)^(1/years) - 1.

summary: Choose the method that matches your data: single-period CAPM for point-in-time comparisons, Jensen-style for regression-derived estimates, and annualized excess for multi-period cumulative returns.

Ensure periodicity alignment and data provenance. For formal reporting and trading or advisory decisions, retain regression diagnostics and data lineage, and follow organizational validation and control processes.
